alerts.message:
The National Weather Service in Cleveland has issued a 

* Flood Warning for 
 the Cuyahoga river at Independence
* from this afternoon until Sunday morning
* at 11:30 am Saturday the stage was...15.5 feet 
* minor flooding is forecast 
* flood stage is 16.0 feet 
* forecast to rise above flood stage by this afternoon and rise to 
 near 16.7 feet by this evening.The river will fall below flood 
 stage by early Sunday morning.
* At 17.0 feet...water reaches Murray and fosdick roads in Valley 
 View. Portions of exchange Road, Wall Street, and Cloverleaf Road 
 inundated.


Lat...Lon 4145 8170 4146 8166 4128 8152 4128 8161

...Flood Watch remains in effect through Sunday afternoon...

The Flood Watch continues for

* portions of Ohio and northwest Pennsylvania...including the 
 following areas...in Ohio...Ashtabula inland...Ashtabula 
 Lakeshore...Cuyahoga...Erie OH...Geauga...Huron...Lake... 
 Lorain...Lucas...Mahoning...Medina...Ottawa...Portage... 
 Sandusky...Seneca...Summit...Trumbull and wood. In northwest 
 Pennsylvania...Crawford PA...northern Erie and southern Erie. 

* Through Sunday afternoon

* ice continues to breakup on area rivers. When the ice moves
 downstream it can jam...which result in flooding...most often in
 upstream locations due to backwater. The still Frozen Lake Erie
 will be a barrier to any ice trying to advance downstream for
 the rivers and creeks that flow into the lake.

* Rain will end from west to east this morning. Rainfall amounts
 in the watch area will range from two tenths to half an inch.
 The rainfall and warmer temperatures will eliminate the
 snow pack completely from all but the snowbelt counties. This
 combined runoff will increase the flood threat across the area
 this weekend...but especially for those communities already
 impacted by ice jams. River levels could rise very abruptly
 which could lead to the development of additional ice jams.

Precautionary/preparedness actions...

Ice jam flooding is difficult to predict...and conditions can
change rapidly as a jam forms and breaks. The worst flooding
associated with ice jams is often immediately upstream of the jam
location. If you live along or near rivers prone to ice jams...be
prepared to act quickly.
